Bi-functional oxide-zeotype catalytic systems can convert CO2 to light olefins, but at low conversions. Knowledge of the active sites for methanol synthesis over the oxide and the synergy with the zeotype at different operating conditions can guide future improvements. Here we investigate catalysts based on H-SAPO-34 combined with either ZnAl2O4 or ZnGa2O4. We show that the methanol synthesis activity of the metal oxide is dependent on the Zn-content; the activity increases dramatically when Zn content exceeds the stoichiometric level, Zn/(Zn + M) > 0.33 for M = Al or Ga. This creates supported surface ZnO domains, which selectively produce methanol and DME. Combining either of the Zn-spinel catalysts with H-SAPO-34 showed a light olefin selectivity > 70 carbon mol% among the hydrocarbon products, but at a low CO2 to hydrocarbon conversion of ∼3 %. Co-feeding CO increased the CO2 to hydrocarbon conversion significantly without affecting the olefin selectivity. Demands for plastic materials are forecasted to increase by ∼20 % by 2030 [1]. Ethylene and propylene are mainly produced from steam cracking of naphtha and fluid catalytic cracking of heavier crude oil fractions. The production of plastic materials generates ∼1.6 billion tons of CO2 equivalent, which accounts for around 3 % of the global greenhouse gas emissions [1]. Thus, finding alternative ways of producing these chemicals is essential to reduce their impact. Combining captured CO2 with H2 produced from water electrolysis for the production of light olefins could be an attractive pathway and has received increasing interest in literature [2–5]. Two CO2 utilization technologies have shown promising performance: The combination of reverse-water-gas-shift with Fischer-Tropsch synthesis or the combination of methanol synthesis with the methanol-to-hydrocarbons reaction. Recent research has demonstrated that an iron based Fischer-Tropsch catalyst promoted with alkali metal enhanced the light olefin selectivity [6–9], but the polymerization reaction followed the Anderson-Schulz-Flory distribution limiting the C2–4 selectivity to ∼60 % [10]. However, the combined methanol synthesis and methanol-to-hydrocarbon process has shown ≥ 80 selectivity towards light olefins [2,3,11]. When mixing a methanol synthesis catalyst with solid acids within one reactor, the immediate dehydration of the methanol enables the direct conversion of CO2 into hydrocarbons [11]. The local methanol removal shifts the equilibrium and allows operation at lower pressures than those employed in dedicated methanol synthesis processes. However, the combination of methanol synthesis and dehydration in one reactor necessitates a number of compromises [12]. High CO2 conversion and low CO selectivity (from reverse water-gas shift) are essential for high productivity. Industrial CuZnAl methanol synthesis catalysts meet these requirements at lower temperatures around 220–260 °C, but the methanol dehydration component requires higher temperatures for the hydrocarbon formation, typically ≥ 370 °C for light olefins formation. To avoid the hydrogenation of the formed olefins, less active oxide-based methanol synthesis catalysts without metallic components (such as Cu or Pd) are needed [13–16], solid acids with low acid site density and strength, and operating at relatively low H2 partial pressure is suitable for this purpose [17,18]. Specifically, a ZnO-based methanol synthesis catalyst combined with H-SAPO-34 has shown promising results for the direct conversion of CO2 to olefins [3,4,19]. Lui et al. [19] reported a light olefins selectivity of 86 %, obtained by combining ZnGa2O4 and H-SAPO-34. The high olefin selectivity was obtained at a CO2 to hydrocarbon conversion of ∼6 %. A comparable olefins selectivity of 87 % was observed when using a combination of ZnAl2O4 and H-SAPO-34 [4]. Still, this high olefin selectivity was attained at a relatively low CO2 to hydrocarbon conversion of around 6 % under the same conditions of 370 °C and 30 bar. These results demonstrated that the Zn-spinel structure had low olefin hydrogenation activity. However, it would be desirable to improve the methanol synthesis activity of the ZnO-based catalysts to maximize the olefin productivity in combined systems, and this requires an improved understanding of the sites responsible for methanol formation. It has been suggested that the methanol synthesis activity depends on the concentration of surface available oxygen vacancies, which are formed when Zn is incorporated into the spinel structure [4,19,20]. However, the methanol synthesis activity over Zn chromite was shown to be dependent on small ZnO sites present on the surface when a non-stoichiometric Zn content was used [21–23]. The formation of surface ZnO has shown a great impact on the methanol synthesis activity for the ZnAl2O4 [24]. In this study we report a fundamental understanding of the methanol synthesis reaction over ZnAl2O4 and ZnGa2O4 catalysts, as well as their utilization in direct CO2 to light olefins. A series of ZnAl2O4 and ZnGa2O4 with varying Zn-contents were prepared by co-precipitation and combined with H-SAPO-34 for the direct conversion of CO2 into light olefins. Reaction conditions were systematically investigated to improve both CO2 conversion and light olefins selectivity. The Zn-spinel catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), and N2 adsorption/desorption (BET). Furthermore, the species involved in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction on the surface of the Zn-spinel catalysts were characterized by in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). The changes in the structure of the supported ZnO were investigated by in-situ XAS under reducing and oxidizing conditions, simulating operation and regeneration cycles of a bifunctional catalyst. We conclude that amorphous ZnO domains on the surface, rather than the spinel phases themselves, are the most active and selective sites for the methanol synthesis. Despite using an optimized methanol synthesis catalyst, the light olefins productivity was low, as conditions increasing conversion lowered selectivity significantly. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of ZnAl2O4 and ZnGa2O4 catalysts with different Zn content between 20 and 50 mol%, defined as Zn/(Zn + M) ⸱100 % where M = Al or Ga, were prepared by the co-precipitation method proposed by Liu et al. This catalyst is hereafter denoted as (0.39)ZnAl2O4, where the number in parentheses represents the Zn mole fraction Zn/(Zn + M) in the catalyst. The prepared solution was heated to 70 °C and ammonium hydroxide was added dropwise under vigorous stirring to reach pH 7. The mixture was aged for 120 min at 70 °C, filtered, and washed with demineralized water. The collected solid was dried at 100 °C overnight and calcined in air at 500 °C for 5 h. The NH4-SAPO-34 sample was obtained from ACS Material®. Zn-SAPO-34 was prepared by incipient wetness impregnation with a Zn(NO3)2·6 H2O solution to prepare ∼1 wt% Zn onto the NH4-SAPO-34. In order to enhance the methanol synthesis activity and discern the active sites associated with Zn-spinel structures, a series of catalysts with different Zn contents were prepared and tested in a fixed bed reactor. The methanol synthesis rate depended on the Zn-content of the Zn-spinel structures, as shown in Fig. 1(a). When the Zn content, defined as Zn/(Zn + M), exceeded the stoichiometric spinel ratio of 0.33 for M = Al or Ga, a significant increase in the methanol synthesis rate was observed. This enhancement was a result of the increased CO2 conversion and higher oxygenate selectivity, as shown in Fig. 1(b). The XRD patterns of the catalysts mainly showed the spinel structure as shown in Fig. 1(c) and Fig S1. The major activity rise for over-stoichiometric Zn contents suggests that it is free ZnO outside the spinel structure that is the dominant active site. As the Zn content further increased beyond stoichiometric Zn, crystalline ZnO became visible by XRD. This caused the methanol synthesis rate to decline (Fig. 1(a)) due to a decrease in the CO2 conversion. The correlation between declining activity and the emergence of crystalline ZnO suggests that the sintering of ZnO species leads to the elimination of the active surface area. Together, these results suggest that the active phase is not inherent to the spinel structures themselves [4,19,28], but rather to a ZnO domain that forms on the surface of the spinel structure [21–24,29]. XAS analysis of the Zn K-edge was conducted to further investigate the nature of the ZnO species present in the spinel catalysts. The X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and the Fourier-transformed k3-weighted extended X-ray absorption fine structure (FT-EXAFS) spectra of the as-prepared ZnAl2O4 catalysts and ZnO are presented in Fig. 2(a) and (b). A similar analysis for the ZnGa2O4 was conducted and can be found in Fig. S1. Fitting the two nearest neighbor shells to the FT-EXAFS spectrum of the sub-stoichiometric ZnAl2O4 sample, using paths calculated for ZnAl2O4 (ICSD 196109), found Zn-O at 1.96 Å, Zn-Al at 3.34 Å, and Zn-Zn at 3.50 Å. When using similar paths calculated for ZnGa2O4 (ICSD 81108) to fit the sub-stoichiometric ZnGa2O4 sample found Zn-O at 1.98 Å, Zn-Ga 3.44 Å, and Zn-Zn 3.57 Å. This confirmed that Zn in these samples was present in the spinel structure, where Zn atoms are tetrahedrally coordinated within the octahedrally coordinated aluminum oxide or gallium oxide structure. Changes in both the XANES (Fig. 2(a)) and EXAFS (Fig. 2(b)) spectra were observed as the Zn-content increased. Signals associated with crystalline ZnO (ICSD 57450) became visible at high Zn-contents, in agreement with the observations from the XRD analysis (Fig. 1(c)). The EXAFS fits of the standards and the Zn-O, Zn-Zn (ZnO), and Zn-Al, Zn-Zn (ZnAl2O4) contributions to the fitted curve are shown in Fig. S2. Similar fits for the ZnGa2O4 catalyst can be found in Fig S3. Linear combination fitting of the XANES spectra was conducted to further understand the changes in ZnO phases present in the catalysts between low and high Zn contents. In previous work, amorphous, surface ZnO was observed at low Zn contents for ZnO supported on alumina stabilized tetragonal zirconia catalysts[27]. This catalyst was used as a spectral reference for supported amorphous ZnO. The spectra of the sub-stoichiometric spinel catalysts and of bulk ZnO were used as references for the spinel bound Zn and crystalline ZnO respectively. Good fits were obtained by using these three references (Figs. S4 and S5, Table S1), showing that the changes in the spectra were caused by the formation of an amorphous surface ZnO domain that at high Zn contents formed crystalline ZnO. The outcomes of linear combination fitting, as presented in Table 1, indicate that methanol synthesis activity increased associated with the formation of the amorphous ZnO domains, while it declined with the formation of crystalline ZnO (Fig. 1(a) and Table 1). By utilizing the bulk concentration determined from ICP analysis and the fraction of Zn present as the surface ZnO domains (Table 1), the number of the surface ZnO species in these domains was estimated [27]. Notably, the methanol synthesis rate exhibited a strong correlation with estimated amount of surface ZnO species, as depicted in Fig. 2(c). This finding shows that the surface ZnO domains are the primary active sites for methanol synthesis and that improving the amount of these domains, e.g. by increasing the surface area available to support them, will enhance the methanol synthesis activity [24,27]. The spinel phases themselves did show methanol synthesis activity, as the correlation in Fig. 2(c) does not show zero rate if no surface ZnO is present, but the catalysts became more selective towards oxygenates rather than CO with increasing amounts of ZnO surface domains (Fig. 1(b)). 3.2 Changes in the ZnO phase under reducing and oxidizing atmospheres In-situ XAS analysis at the Zn K-edge was conducted on the most active spinel catalysts under methanol synthesis conditions and under changing reducing and oxidizing atmospheres, simulating catalyst regeneration in a bi-functional catalyst system. The XANES and EXAFS spectra obtained at room temperature after the dehydration step and after periodic switching between H2 or syngas and O2 are illustrated in Fig. 3(a) and (b) for the (0.39)ZnAl2O4 catalyst. The dehydration step did not change the structure of the catalysts compared to the as-prepared state (Fig. 2(a-b)). However, the periodic switching between reducing and oxidizing gasses caused the formation of crystalline ZnO and led to a deactivated catalyst (Fig. 3(c)). Using both H2 and a syngas mixture as the reducing gas gave similar results (Fig. 3(a-b)). Thus, the sintering of the surface ZnO domain into crystalline ZnO under oscillating conditions leads to catalyst deactivation, providing additional confirmation that the sintering of dispersed surface ZnO into crystalline ZnO is associated with a loss of activity. A similar experiment was conducted for the (0.37)ZnGa2O4 catalyst as shown in Fig S6. Linear combination fitting of the (0.37)ZnGa2O4 revealed that the crystalline ZnO fraction doubled after oscillating between syngas and O2, as illustrated in Fig S6. The instability of the surface ZnO domain under the oscillating conditions indicates that Zn becomes mobile and sinters. It is plausible that Zn exhibits mobility under reducing conditions, as these conditions may contribute to a partial reduction of the surface ZnO [27]. Shifting to oxidizing conditions reoxidizes the more sintered ZnO. Such mobility of the ZnO under reducing conditions could be important for the observed solid-state titration of ZnO into zeolite components in bi-functional catalytic systems [30–32]. Furthermore, zinc mobility under reducing atmospheres is debated in literature to have an important effect on copper based methanol synthesis catalysts as well [33–35]. The deactivation behavior of the metal oxide catalysts under alternating reducing-oxidizing conditions could be a significant drawback when used together with H-SAPO-34. H-SAPO-34 deactivates fast due to carbon deposits hindering access to the acid sites under methanol-to-olefins conditions [36]. Oxidative removal of such carbon deposits when using the bi-functional catalytic system would deactivate the methanol synthesis catalyst. However, great stability has been demonstrated when combining metal oxides solid with CHA acids [2–4,18,19,37], so oxidative regeneration may be unnecessary. 3.3 The CO2 hydrogenation to methanol mechanism In-situ DRIFTS was utilized to investigate the CO2 hydrogenation reaction over Zn-containing spinel structures. As shown in Fig. 4(a), ZnAl2O4 was initially exposed to CO2 adsorption at 320 °C, resulting in the formation of carbonate species (*CO3) detected at 1371 and 1552 cm−1 [38–41]. Upon switching the gas from CO2 to H2, the surface carbonate rapidly hydrogenated into formate species (*HCOO), which were detected at 1363, 1375, 1598, and 2850 cm−1 (Fig. 4(a-b) and Fig. S7) [39,42,43]. Subsequently, the formate peaks began to diminish under a constant H2 flow, accompanied by the simultaneous formation of water and CH4. This was detected in the gas phase as the “hedgehog” signal, attributed to the rotational modes of water molecules observed around 1300–2000 cm−1, and the peak at 1306 cm−1, respectively (Fig. 4(a)). Both the ZnAl2O4 and ZnGa2O4 catalysts showed low selectivity towards CH4 under the methanol synthesis conditions, but the high IR absorption cross-section for CH4 is believed to be the reason for the strong signal observed. CH4 formation was observed by Ye et al. [44] over a similar ZnAl2O4 catalyst. Fig. S8 illustrates that the ZnGa2O4 catalyst exhibits a similar trend in CO2 adsorption as carbonate species, followed by the formation of formate in the presence of H2 gas. Repeating this experiment at 260 °C over ZnAl2O4 showed the formation of carbonate, which again rapidly hydrogenated into surface formate. However, the fast removal of the formate peaks by further hydrogenation in constant H2 flow was not observed (Fig. S7). This could indicate that formate hydrogenation proceeds much slower and requires more energy to overcome the activation energy barrier than carbonate hydrogenation. 3.4 Direct CO2 hydrogenation into olefins The measurements of direct CO2 hydrogenation to olefins activity were conducted by physical mixing of granulates of the metal oxide and H-SAPO-34 within one reactor. By combining the (0.39)ZnAl2O4 with H-SAPO-34, a light olefin selectivity of 80 mol% on a carbon basis within the hydrocarbon products was obtained at 10 bar and 400 °C ( Fig. 5(a)). This light olefin selectivity was achieved with a CO2 to hydrocarbons conversion (CO x conversion) of 2.9 %. By changing the metal oxide component to (0.37)ZnGa2O4 or (0.18)ZnO/t-ZrO2, the CO x conversion increased to 3.8 and 5.4 %, respectively. Detailed analysis of the methanol synthesis activity of the ZnO/t-ZrO2 catalyst is published elsewhere [27]. The improvements in the CO x conversion were achieved with the drawback of a decrease in light olefin selectivity to 72 and 67 carbon mol%. However, due to the enhanced CO x conversion, the light olefin formation rates were 22 and 11 gC2–4= kg−1 h−1 for the ZnO/t-ZrO2 and the ZnAl2O4 catalyst, respectively (Fig S9). For comparison, the productivity levels for dedicated methanol synthesis with the oxides is on the order of 500 gMeOH kg−1 h−1 (Fig. 1(a)) and the productivity level for industrial Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts for methanol synthesis is around 5000 gMeOH kg−1 h−1 [45]. Hence the light olefins productivity is on a low level, which is a general drawback of direct CO2 to olefins using bifunctional catalysts. Increasing the reactor pressure improved the CO x conversion for the ZnAl2O4 catalyst, as illustrated in Fig. 5(b). In Fig. 5(c), the calculated hydrogen index as a function of pressure for all three catalyst combinations is visualized. A hydrogen index of 1.00 corresponds to no incorporation of gaseous H2 into the product, meaning that all hydrogen stored in the product came from methanol dehydration, forming the “CH2“-hydrocarbon pool species. A hydrogen index above or below 1 corresponds to hydrogenation or dehydrogenation, respectively. The result in Fig. 5(c) shows, that the catalyst mixture of the metal oxide and H-SAPO-34 all resulted in net hydrogenation. As the pressure increased, the incorporation of gaseous H2 also increased, which explains the decreased light olefin selectivity with increasing pressure observed in Fig. 5(b). At low pressures, the ZnAl2O4 catalyst had a hydrogen index closer to one, compared to the other catalysts, showing less hydrogenation activity. However, similar hydrogenation activity was observed for all three catalyst mixtures when the pressure increased to ≥ 20 bar. To investigate how performance changes with the presence of CO in the feed gas, CO co-feeding experiments were conducted, which mimics the process of recycling unconverted gas back to the reactor. The CO co-feeding was conducted according to two different strategies. The results represented in Fig. 6 were obtained by replacing CO2 with CO while keeping the total amount of carbon constant. Experiments where the CO or the CO2 partial pressures were kept constant while co-feeding of either CO2 or CO can be found in Fig. S10. As depicted in Fig. 6(a), having more CO in the feed gas led to a decrease in both CO selectivity and CO2 conversion. The CO selectivity dropped from 91 % to 35 %, where the CO2 conversion only decreased from 27 % to 15 %, resulting in an increased overall CO x conversion from 2.3 % to 9.5 %. This was achieved without affecting the olefin selectivity, which remained constant at 79 carbon mol% (Fig. 6(a)). Therefore, the increased presence of CO in the feed resulted in an enhanced rate of light olefin formation, rising from 10 to 18 gC2–4= kg−1 h−1, as illustrated in Fig. 6(b). These results demonstrate a powerful strategy to minimize the CO selectivity and improve the light olefin formation rate for the bi-functional catalytic system, which could be achieved by recycling gas to the reactor [4,46]. The methanol selectivity within the hydrocarbons for the CO co-feeding experiment was less than 0.5 carbon mole%, indicating near-complete methanol conversion over the SAPO-34 catalyst component in the reactor. Several factors may account for the enhanced CO x conversion observed during CO co-feeding. Firstly, CO could potentially serve as the primary carbon source for the initial methanol synthesis. Also, CO may aid in the removal of water, an inhibitor of the metal oxide that slows the methanol synthesis activity [47]. Additionally, CO may generate oxygen vacancies that boost the CO2 hydrogenation rate [48]. Lastly, CO may facilitate the carbonylation of hydrocarbon pool species [49]. Prior dedicated methanol synthesis studies on ZnO have suggested that CO2 is the primary carbon source for methanol, so it is unlikely that CO affects the reaction by opening a new path to methanol. Instead, an analysis of the water gas shift equilibrium suggests that the CO feeding mainly benefits the reaction by limiting the concentration of water. Kinetic analysis of a bi-functional catalytic system showed that the produced methanol and water may easily lower the thermodynamic driving force [50]. On-going kinetic analysis within our group show that accurately fitting the experimental data requires considerations of the role of water, in agreement with the findings of the group of Olsbye [50]. Specifically, water either restricts the thermodynamic equilibrium or necessitates the inclusion of a water inhibition term in the CO2 to methanol reaction model. As the experimental data in the kinetic analysis did not show a global CO2 to methanol equilibrium, we conclude that the loss of activity with increasing water content can be attributed to the competitive adsorption of water on the active sites of the metal oxide. As illustrated in Fig. 6(c), in these experiments, the outlet gas composition was far from achieving equilibrium in the CO2 to methanol conversion. Fig. 6(c) depicts that the reverse-water-gas-shift reaction reached equilibrium when a high amount of CO was co-fed. Therefore, the production of water from this reaction was limited, leading to a significant decrease in the total amount of water in the reactor. The water outlet concentration decreased from 7.1 mol% to 2.0 mol%. Thus, the enhanced activity could be due to the lower water content improving the reaction rate of the CO2 to methanol hydrogenation reaction. Lastly, incorporation of CO into the hydrocarbon pool species within the solid acid pores cannot be excluded [49,51], but it seems unlikely as no significant change was observed in the hydrocarbon distribution (Fig. 6(a)). The effect on the hydrocarbon distribution and light olefin formation rate with the change of residence time in the reactor when feeding CO2/H2 over the ZnAl2O4 and H-SAPO-34 is illustrated in Fig. 7. Short residence time allows unconverted methanol and dimethyl ether to pass through the reactor. At longer residence time, the oxygenates were converted and an increase in the light olefin selectivity was observed (Fig. 7(a)). With extended residence time, the olefin selectivity began to decline, attributed to the hydrogenation of olefins into paraffins. The optimum olefin selectivity was obtained when all oxygenates were converted into olefins while the residence time remained sufficiently short to prevent olefin hydrogenation. As shown in Fig. 7(b), the CO selectivity did not change with the change in residence time and remained stable at ∼90 %. However, the CO2 conversion increased from 12.7 % to 27.5 % with a 5.7-time increase in the residence time. This trend in CO2 conversion can be attributed to water limiting the CO2 to methanol reaction as more water is formed at a longer residence time. The optimum light olefin formation rate was achieved at the residence time where all the oxygenates were converted and where the CO2 hydrogenation reaction was not influenced by water, as depicted in Fig. 7(b). Hence, industrial implementation of bi-functional catalyst systems for direct syngas to hydrocarbons may necessitate a reconsideration of reactor design to eliminate the high concentration of water [52]. The stability of the ZnAl2O4+H-SAPO-34 catalyst mixture was investigated, and the results are shown in Fig. 8. A slow but steady deactivation was observed for the CO2 conversion over 100 h on stream. Greater changes were observed for the CO, light olefin, and light paraffin selectivities, mainly within the first 10 h on stream. The decline in light olefin selectivity was attributed to an increase in hydrogenation activity, resulting in a higher paraffin selectivity. Additionally, the CO selectivity increased showing a decrease in CO2 converted into hydrocarbons within the initial 10 h. After the first 10 h, stable selectivities were observed for more than 90 h. These results demonstrate a stable catalytic system, in sharp contrast to the methanol-to-olefins process. Similar trends with time on stream have been reported for bi-functional catalysts [3,18], but the cause of the stable performance is still not fully known. The results in Fig. 8(b) show that more than 18 gMeOH pr gSAPO-34 was converted without a significant drop in the methanol conversion. This surpasses the methanol-to-olefin process where the CHA structure is prone to fast deactivation by internal coke formation. Bleken et al. [36] showed that SAPO-34 can convert approximately 20 gMeOH pr gSAPO-34 before the methanol conversion dropped to 20 %. The combination of the metal oxide, the solid acid, and the reaction atmosphere has an enhancing effect on the solid acid's lifetime. Improved lifetime for the methanol-to-olefins process has been demonstrated by co-feeding methanol with a high partial pressure of H2 [53–55]. This enhancement was attributed to a decrease in the rate of coke formation, resulting in smaller coke molecules, primarily mono- and diaromatics, as opposed to the tri- and tetraaromatic species typically formed during the methanol-to-olefins process [13,54]. Zhao et al. [55] proposed that hydrogenation of heavy aromatic deposits reactivates these aromatic species for the hydrocarbon pool mechanism and thus slows down the evolution of coke species. Furthermore, studies have shown that high partial pressures of water together with H2 further reduce the amount of coke formed [55,56]. Combining a Zn-based methanol synthesis catalyst with a solid acid catalyst can result in the titration of acidic sites through Zn ion exchange into the solid acid [30,31]. To simulate this, a SAPO-34 sample was impregnated with a small amount of Zn, denoted Zn-SAPO-34. This catalyst was combined with ZnAl2O4, tested for its direct CO2 hydrogenation to olefin abilities, and compared to H-SAPO-34, as illustrated in Fig. 9(a-b). XRF analysis revealed the presence of 1.5 wt% Zn in the Zn-SAPO-34 sample, leading to a reduction in acid site density from 516 to 403 µmol/g, as determined by NH3-TPD (Table S2). XRD analysis did not detect the presence of any crystalline ZnO in the Zn-SAPO-34 sample (Fig. 9(c)), confirming the absence of large ZnO clusters. Consequently, it was inferred that the Zn was well dispersed and occupied acid sites within the SAPO-34 crystals. Upon combination with ZnAl2O4, the CO2 conversion and CO selectivity were identical to those observed with the ZnAl2O4/H-SAPO-34 catalyst (Fig. 9(a)). However, the hydrogenation activity of the Zn-SAPO-34 catalyst, illustrated by the hydrogen index in Fig. 9(b), was significantly higher yielding a higher selectivity towards paraffins. This suggests that Zn migration from ZnAl2O4 into H-SAPO-34 was responsible for the decrease in olefin selectivity, where the greatest change happens within the first 10 h on stream (Fig. 9(a-b)). Zn migration further altered the active site for the methanol synthesis reaction, which could explain the initial changes in the CO2 and CO selectivity (Fig. 9(a)). XRD analysis of the catalysts after being exposed to CO2 to olefins conditions (from experiments visualized in Fig. 5(b) and S9) showed that both the ZnAl2O4 and ZnO crystals sintered, with an increase in crystallite size from 33 to 72 Å and from 109 to 230 Å, respectively. Similar sintering was observed for ZnGa2O4, where the crystallite size increased from 79 to 137 Å. Crystalline ZnO was not visible by XRD for the ZnGa2O4 catalyst. This demonstrates that the metal oxide loses active surface area with time on stream and explains the slow and steady loss in the CO2 conversion. Overall, this suggested that two potential deactivation phenomena may occur: Zn migration, which occurs initially, increasing the hydrogenation activity of the solid acid, and metal oxide sintering, which steadily removes the methanol synthesis active surface area. 3.5 Potential process discussion The direct production of olefins from CO2 using bi-functional catalysts is primarily limited by the trade-off between conversion and selectivity. At low conversion rates, the process would require a large compressor to recycle unconverted synthesis gas, significantly reducing the economic viability of the process. One potential solution involves the removal of water through a membrane reactor system, which could enhance methanol synthesis activity and, in turn, improve CO2 conversion [57]. However, further research is necessary to evaluate the operational feasibility and optimization of such a reactor system. Another approach could focus on the development of zeolite-type materials with modified acidity to inhibit olefin hydrogenation while maintaining olefin production. These materials would enable efficient methanol conversion without significant hydrogenation activity. Such modifications could allow for operation at higher pressures without compromising olefin selectivity, thereby achieving higher CO2 conversion rates [58,59]. However, it appears difficult to compete with the commercialized two-step process of separate methanol synthesis using the highly active Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst in a dedicated reactor, followed by olefin production over SAPO-34 in a fluidized bed reactor. This approach provides greater flexibility and control over reaction conditions. 4 Conclusions To improve the methanol synthesis activity for ZnAl2O4 and ZnGa2O4, the Zn content should exceed the stoichiometric spinel content. Exceeding the stoichiometric content creates ZnO domains on the spinel structure’s surface, which can be quantified by XAS analysis. These sites have superior oxygenate selectivity, and the concentration of such sites controls the CO2 conversion. However, at high Zn content, the formation of crystalline ZnO removes these amorphous ZnO domains, resulting in a decrease in the methanol synthesis activity. In-situ XAS analysis confirms that the primary active sites are the amorphous surface ZnO domains since deactivation occurs with the formation of crystalline ZnO when oscillating between reducing and oxidizing conditions. In-situ DRIFTS analysis shows that the CO2 to methanol reaction over Zn-containing spinel catalyst occurs through a formate pathway, where CO2 adsorbs as carbonate, hydrogenates into formate, and further into methoxy, which desorbs as methanol. When the Zn spinel catalysts are combined with H-SAPO-34 solid acid, a high olefin selectivity is observed. ZnGa2O4 has higher methanol synthesis activity and higher hydrogen index, showing a higher olefin hydrogenation activity than the ZnAl2O4 catalyst. By increasing the pressure, higher hydrocarbon yields are obtained at the expense of an increase in paraffin selectivity. This demonstrates a trade-off between the CO2 conversion to hydrocarbons and the olefin selectivity, which is a general limitation of direct CO2 to olefins using bifunctional catalysts. Co-feeding CO is a strategy to improve the CO2 conversion to hydrocarbons without affecting the olefin selectivity. Co-feeding CO decreases the rate of the reverse-water-gas-shift reaction by limiting the thermodynamic driving force. This causes minimal production of water, which increases the rate of the CO2 to methanol reaction. Combining the ZnAl2O4 and H-SAPO-34 shows stable production of olefins for around 100 h on stream and shows that more than 18 gMeOH per gSAPO-34 can be converted without any reduction in the methanol conversion. Deactivation was observed with time on stream and two potential deactivation phenomena may occur: Zn migration into the zeolite and sintering of the metal oxide. XRD analysis of the spent catalyst indicated metal oxide sintering, which may account for the gradual but consistent decline in CO2 conversion over time. Furthermore, Zn impregnation into the solid acid enhanced its hydrogenation activity. Therefore, the solid-state migration of Zn could explain the initial reduction in olefin selectivity observed within the first 10 h on stream. CRediT authorship contribution statement M.T. coredata.dc:description: Bi-functional oxide-zeotype catalytic systems can convert CO2 to light olefins, but at low conversions. Knowledge of the active sites for methanol synthesis over the oxide and the synergy with the zeotype at different operating conditions can guide future improvements. Here we investigate catalysts based on H-SAPO-34 combined with either ZnAl2O4 or ZnGa2O4. We show that the methanol synthesis activity of the metal oxide is dependent on the Zn-content; the activity increases dramatically when Zn content exceeds the stoichiometric level, Zn/(Zn + M) > 0.33 for M = Al or Ga. This creates supported surface ZnO domains, which selectively produce methanol and DME. Combining either of the Zn-spinel catalysts with H-SAPO-34 showed a light olefin selectivity > 70 carbon mol% among the hydrocarbon products, but at a low CO2 to hydrocarbon conversion of ∼3 %. Co-feeding CO increased the CO2 to hydrocarbon conversion significantly without affecting the olefin selectivity.
